utterance.speaker: Susan
utterance.content: I still can't believe you talked me into this.

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: Come on, honey. You're gonna throw him off.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: It's okay. I'm almost done. A little more light on your hips.

utterance.speaker: Susan
utterance.content: Oh, God. Why couldn't you have come up with this before I had two kids?

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: You look amazing.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Okay, I think… yeah, I'm done. Wanna come take a look?

utterance.speaker: Susan
utterance.content: I can’t. You first.

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: No, we'll look together.

utterance.speaker: Susan
utterance.content: I don't understand. I… I thought —

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: What the hell is that?

utterance.speaker: Susan
utterance.content: Honey. It's okay.

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: This is not what we discussed, or what I paid for.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I don't understand. I think this is one of the best I've ever done.

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: I want my money back.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I'm sorry, but this is not some department store photo studio.

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: And this is not my wife.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Yes, it is. You asked me to paint her exactly as she looks. That's exactly what I did.

utterance.speaker: Susan
utterance.content: Honey! Oh, stop it!

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: What's going on? Brandon!

utterance.speaker: Anthony
utterance.content: That check… better be in my mailbox by Friday. Or I'll be back. Come on!

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I don't know. They saw the painting and they just freaked out.

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: Brandon, what is this?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: What do you mean? It's her portrait. What's wrong with it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why's this in here?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: First column, last entry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Today is going to be a good day.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She means are you the private investigator whose bills I've tried to slip through as medical expenses?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Oh. Hi. I'm Lucas Douglas, PI.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This hospital's not putting a private investigator on retainer. Nor is it gonna pay any more phony repairs on vending machines, cryostats, or elevators.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Information saves lives. Saving lives saves money.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, saving lives costs money, which is why I'm trying to make sure there's still some left! You want your own personal PI, you're gonna have to pay for him yourself. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: No, I understand. Hey, I… I like the shoes, by the way.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Uh… thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't like her shoes. You like her legs.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: It sounds less creepy if you say shoes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Less creepy, more gay.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: That's my firm's motto. What is a cryostat?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No idea. Whoever fixed ours is about to get stiffed.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: There's no distorted perspective in any of his other recent works.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Not much talent, either.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So the symptoms just came on. Acute onset visual agnosia points to a stroke or brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: MRI revealed no stroke or brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We should do another with contrast.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If he's like the other struggling artists I've known, he's also into drugs. We should… What are you looking at?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Apparently, a moron. One, ER routinely tests for drugs. If it was positive, we wouldn't be looking at this file. Two, who pays 12% interest on a car loan?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: How did you —? Did you run a credit check on me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. That would be illegal. Interestingly enough, paying someone to run it for me, though… What? It's part of my job.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Your job is to diagnose patients.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which I do with the team. How am I supposed to know how best to utilize that team if I don't know everything about them? Say that Van Gogh turns out to have neurosyphilis, and our last vial of penicillin is in a storeroom at the end of a 20-mile hallway with a two-foot high ceiling.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You've discovered that one of us has been hiding the ability to stretch or shrink themselves?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I would never out someone's super powers. This, on the other hand…

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You crawled 20 miles?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: My name's in the Guinness book.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I'll bet that really impresses the babes.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I didn't do it to get the babes.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No. That would cheapen the purity of your achievement.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sorry to interrupt, but we have a patient with a probable brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Who needs an MRI with contrast, we've established that. What do you got on Taub?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I got nothing on Taub.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Could also be environmental. We should check his studio for toxins, mold, fungus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Taub's wife, on the other hand…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House. That's enough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dad's right. This is no time for gossip. A patient desperately needs our help. Check his head and his house.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Can't Lucas —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. He's very busy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If there is a tumor, this test will show us —

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Is that stuff dangerous?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: This is just the contrast material. There is a small risk of an anaphylactic reaction.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I could stop breathing?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Don't worry. We're prepared to deal with whatever happens.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: You know, I did some drawings this morning, and they seemed fine. So maybe it was just a reaction to something I ate.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How many people you know have reactions like that to something they ate for breakfast?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: But if I'm getting better…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’ll continue to get better. If you're not, we need to know why not so we can start treatment immediately.

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: Baby, let them do the test.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Can lead poisoning cause visual agnosia?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Not without lead showing up in the blood work. Nothing in the medicine cabinet except some harmless toiletries. No signs of mold or fungus anywhere, either.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You think House really got something on your wife?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No. Not that I'd care if he did.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Wait, your wife's doing the doorman in your bed, and they're sweating all over the sheets that you paid for and —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: My wife's not doing the doorman.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: How do you know?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We don't have a doorman. And I just do, okay? Drop it.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: In college, my friends and I came up with an inverse-square law.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Sounds like a real fun group.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The girls who you think are the most inhibited… straight arrows… They're the ones you hook up with.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Are you saying my wife's a slut?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I'm saying if my wife was a slut, I'd wanna know.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: His place was clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So is his head. Even with contrast, no masses, no lesions. A neurological symptom with no apparent neurological cause.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Time course means we can rule out cancer and MS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just leaves toxins or drugs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You called Thirteen a moron for thinking it was drugs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. When she said it, she had other options. And I really just wanted to segue into her stupid loan and your —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A cavernous angioma in the brain could leak. Once the blood gets reabsorbed, the pressure goes down, the symptom goes away.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He'll never consent to petrosal vein sampling.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He was nervous about an injection of contrast.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is his girlfriend hot? I'm not talking fever here. I mean, is she all curvy and perky?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Very… and if he dies, it's good news for all of us, but —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That explains why all his paintings suck. And what's wrong with him.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To tell him he may have a massive brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He doesn't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know. I'm not a moron. It's drugs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You seem to have a massive brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Who are you?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He's Dr. House. He's pleased to meet you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We found no trace on any of your imaging, so we need to cut your head open. It's risky, but it's the only way to save your life.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wrong answer.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I'm not allowed to say no?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're not allowed to not be terrified. There's only two good reasons not to be terrified in a hospital. You're delusional. But then you're not afraid of contrast material either. Or you know you're fine. Since we haven't told you you're fine, you obviously have information that we don't have. What drugs are you on?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: His drug tests were clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Drug tests only test for drugs they've made tests for.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hottie thinks that he's a great artist, selling art to the rich and tasteful. She's stupid enough to be fooled by the canvases, but bank accounts don't lie. He needed money. There's not many jobs you can do that don't require time, training, and intelligence. And I know you're not a news anchor or a supermodel, 'cause those jobs seldom cause agnosia. He's a guinea pig. Companies pay him to test their untested drugs. Did hottie go for a pee or coffee? Either way, I don't think we should waste any time on denials.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: The clinical trials were supposed to be safe. The drugs are about to be approved by the FDA.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Drugs? How many trials are you on?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Three.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Admirable. Not many idiots have that much ambition. You've been symptom-free since your admission, so whatever you took has probably cleared your system now. You'll be fine. Keep him overnight, just to make sure, and get the names of all the trials he's been in.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: You gonna tell Heather?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Couldn't, even if I cared enough to want to.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not bad. You almost made it the whole day.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What'd you find out?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The point is to see how everyone reacts. Let me go get the rest of the gang.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Cut the crap, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your wife has a separate bank account in her name only. She's been making weekly cash deposits for about a year now. No withdrawals… yet.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: That's it? A bank account?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A secret bank account.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What makes you think it's a secret?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because if it wasn't, you'd call it "the" bank account.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Damn. Always forget to use the right article when lying. It's not secret. We're refurnishing. We set the budget, set up an account. I just couldn't make it to the bank the day we opened it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're spending almost $100,000 on furniture?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don't know. He was fine, then all of a sudden, he started seizing.

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: He said you told him he was better. What's happening? What's wrong with him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She is hot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Obviously the drugs weren't out of his system.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: None of these drugs, nor the drugs that they're derived from, are known for causing seizures.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: By themselves, no. But three unproven, untested drugs? It’s like the mod squad. No one could stop them.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Ridiculous that they let people take potentially dangerous drugs for money.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just to short-circuit that discussion, people should not be testing drugs because they're desperate. But people won't test drugs unless they're desperate. We need drugs to save children and puppies. Ergo, we need desperate people. Ergo, welfare kills sick children.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: First drug —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why don't we call it bisexidrine? Clinical trials involve experimental drugs. Means they don't have comforting, catchy names yet. Just random, unmemorable trial numbers. Go ahead.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Bisexidrine is designed as an anticoagulant. Phase one indicated some risk of nausea, ED and insomnia. Second drug.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuckoldisol.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: She is having an affair?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Worse. Sex can be dismissed as hormonal or emotional. Can be easily regretted. Money is always a calculated decision.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: My wife has her own bank account that House doesn't think I know about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shocking. Discuss.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Drug B is an autoimmune treatment. Almost no side effects.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: But even if it's doing what it's supposed to be doing, it doesn't mix well with anticoagulants or anticonvulsives.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Which is the third drug?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Worldssorestkneesisil. Cuddy used to have that title, by the way.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's a million ways these drugs could interact if they're doing what they're supposed to. If they're not, two million.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And it'd be interesting to know which of those interactions was causing the problem. Unfortunately, we don't have to. We just have to stop the interacting.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: If we don't know which —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop them all. Put him on dialysis. Clear out his system.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Rapid detox risks arrhythmia, another seizure, hepatic failure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Difference is, we know what those risks are. Put him on dialysis.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Dialysis. Use that for kidney failure, right?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Don't worry. Your kidneys are fine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He's not worried about his kidneys. He's worried about how he's going to explain the dialysis to his girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I just don't want her to worry.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You mean you don't want her to leave you?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: What's wrong with that? I love her. It's not like I've lied to her about anything important. I am an artist. I've sold plenty of paintings in the past. It's just… I've hit a bit of a dry spell lately, is all.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: So tell her that.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He can't. He wants her to be happy too. He's telling her what she wants to hear.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You didn't know?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What are you gonna do?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She's not sleeping around. She's not gambling it away. She hasn't even spent any of it. So I don't see a reason to do anything.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You don't think a conversation might —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How many people do you know in completely happy and fulfilled relationships?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: None.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I am. Most people cling to some storybook notion of what a relationship is. You can't have an imperfect thought. You can't have a private zone. You can't —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Steal money and hide it away in a secret account?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She makes me happy. I make her happy. It works. Because we don't do storybook. And I don't plan to poke into her business.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You were right about the dialysis. He made it through the night without any more seizures or visual symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And I am going to be just as right after breakfast up in my office. The only difference is I'm gonna be right in front of other people. Which means you're not here to talk about the medicine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You can screw with me all you want at work, but stay out of my personal life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did she say?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Did you just hear what I said?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I heard the part about “you can screw with me at work all you want.”Want my advice?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Of course not.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good, 'cause I have no idea what you should do. I only know what you're going to do. You're gonna —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I said I didn't want your advice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said this is not advice. You are going to forgive her for opening that account, and you're going to confess everything you've done, and then you're gonna beg her to forgive you.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What purpose could that possibly serve?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: None. Which is why I'm not saying you should. But you will.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: What's your end game?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where are you?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: At the track.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's, like, six miles away. How cool are these things?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I feel like an idiot. The woman sitting next to him shifts further away.] I'm not giving you any more of my stuff.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have those night vision goggles?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're lying.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: You like making him miserable. You like driving people away from you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He deserved to know the truth.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: There was no truth until you dug it up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You do know that stuff exists even when you can't see it, right?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: It was a truth that mattered to him and a truth that mattered to her. Why did it matter to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: First of all, stop saying "a" truth. There is only one truth.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: That may be true for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Miserable people save more lives. If your life has meaning, your job doesn't have to have meaning. Screw-ups are more palatable if you have someone's arms to go cry in.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Yeah, that makes sense.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Usually I have more of a fight on that one.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: So why are you making Taub miserable?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just said!

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: He left his last job to save his marriage. If his marriage falls apart, you think he'll be working harder for you or you think he won't be working for you at all?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His head and neck are completely swollen. I need a trache kit. His throat's closing. Can't find any landmarks.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Just start cutting.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: An exploratory trache?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We don't have a choice.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Got it.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: His face is so swollen it squeezed his tear ducts shut. We've been lubricating his eyes by hand. We started him on steroids, IV and cream, to reduce the swelling, but it's having limited effect.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Negative for thrombosis and Chagas. Could be infection.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Culture's still negative.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be his immune system's on hyperdrive. Cytokine storm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would you pay for a three-year gym membership and only go twice? Sorry. You guys still diagnosing? Thought we'd finished hours ago. You remember, when we decided it was the unproven, unapproved cocktail of drugs he's been downing like… well, like a cocktail.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He just completed a total dialysis. If it was the drugs, he'd be better.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or he'd be worse. I take it none of you saw Trainspotting.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You think swelling is a symptom of withdrawal?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think it's a coincidence that three new symptoms cropped up as soon as we took him off the drugs?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's possible some of the symptoms —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either the drugs are the answer, or the drugs are a coincidence. If it's one, we have to find a better way to detox him. If it's two, we have to know which symptoms are withdrawal-related before we can formulate a diagnosis. Which means we have to find a better way to detox him.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So how do we do it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hair of the drug that bit him.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: That's ridiculous. If it is the drugs, they're dangerous, and they've already caused —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's why we're gonna put him back on the drugs, and then wean him off again. Just much slower. Why are you looking at him?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Try it out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You heard the boss! Go!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Taub —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I didn't talk to her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why are you —

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Uh, sorry.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: He does look like me, doesn't he?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You gave him your hat.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I needed you out of here, so I could go through your desk.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Nice blouse. I really like that color on you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Tell House that if he wants to know what I'm doing, all he has to do —

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: It's not House, it's — it's me. I was… I don't know, I was thinking maybe we could get together for a drink or something. I wasn't sure exactly what you like to do. So I thought —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You'd spy on me.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: No. No. Not spying. More like research. I think it's a good idea to get to know a little bit more about a woman before you ask her out. Show you care about more than just what she looks like.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: As romantic as you make that sound, I'm pretty sure that what you're doing is… not so much caring as creepy.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: That's not fair.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You were scrounging through my desk.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: What the hell am I gonna find out? You went to Michigan. You like your sandwiches a little light on mayo. You stay in touch with your mother. You rented the English Patient and you gave money to Amnesty International. There's not one thing I can find out in here that you wouldn't tell a coworker while riding in an elevator. I'm not a creep. I just thought you seemed interesting. I'll go now.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Yeah, these, um… I'll give you embarrassing info on House.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: In exchange for —

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: No, no need for a date. You'd be employing me, so I'd have all the time in the world to ask you all about you, and it would fall under the category of socializing instead of creepy stalking.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And I'd be paying you?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I know it's weird. But if you pay me while I check you out, it's — it's all cool. And you get value. You get leverage against him. Help you keep him in line.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You think I need help keeping House in line?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: No. Nope. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This hospital can't afford —

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Oh, whatever you can afford.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How'd you know I liked roses?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I was in your house last night. No! I'm kidding. Who the hell doesn't like roses?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: I forgot to tell you. The Parker Quartet's gonna play at the library fund raiser. That's it? It was your idea.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: They'll be great.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I couldn't find the letter opener. I went through some of the drawers in your desk looking for it. There were a bunch of statements in there from Jefferson Mutual.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: I was so close.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: To what? You've got $83,000 socked away in a secret account.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Not anymore. I wanted to keep it a surprise, but… I bought you the car.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh, the one that — that I…

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: I knew you would never buy it yourself, so… I've been saving. And it's gonna be delivered on Friday.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You are amazing.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Lucky you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We've gradually reduced your dosage. You're actually drug-free now.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I feel great. Thanks to you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: All part of the job. Your blood pressure's normal. Can you sit up? Hey! What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Ah, ahh!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What happened to his face?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Question is what happened to his hormones? We're gonna need an ice pack in here.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We can rule out the clinical trial drugs at this point. His system has been completely cleaned twice. Unless the drugs found a hiding place under the stairs…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Drugs could have set off a dormant neurological condition.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good point. Coming clean can cause a lot of damage. Alienation, divorce.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: My wife's buying me a car.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was talking about the patient.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You were wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Divorce was metaphorical.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about Kluver-Bucy syndrome? Bilateral lesions in the temporal lobes. Visual agnosia and hyper-sexuality are the key symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good thing he's got that girlfriend. If it's Kluver-Bucy, his brain'll melt down, he'll try to swallow his own hands, and she can take care of him for the rest of his talentless life.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You owe me an apology. Any rationalization you had for meddling in my private life disappeared when she had good reason —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're right. Fact is, nothing I said applies. You had no reason to forgive her. Therefore, no reason to seek forgiveness. No reason to be an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Kluver-Bucy wouldn't explain the seizure or the cytokine storm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Withdrawal complications.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then again, she is handing you a giant gift that you don't think you deserve.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The fact that the MRI showed no lesions on the temporal lobe tends to rule out your lesions on the temporal lobe theory.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The damage can be a circulatory issue rather than structural. We wouldn't see that on the MRI.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman's right. Go call your wife, tell her you're not coming home 'cause you have to give the patient a cranial MR angiogram. Then say good night and hang up.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Odd that a man who can't run would own so many pairs of sneakers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You wanna hang this up when you're done?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I have to find something embarrassing about you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you don't.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I ordered us Indian. Not too embarrassing, just something credible.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if you hand her that, she's not gonna need you anymore.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Well, if I don't hand her anything, she'll think I'm incompetent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't care if she thinks you're incompetent.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: This isn't gonna work.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's worked so far.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: No, I'm no good at lying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know. That's why your cover is that you want to do her.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I like her. I don't wanna do her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then what's the point of liking her?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I meant I don't just want to do her. I like her. What do you think you're gonna find out about her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Something… personal. Something embarrassing. I spend half my life negotiating with that woman. Anything I can use to scare her into saying yes.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay? You're okay with being paid twice to facilitate blackmail?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I'm okay. I don't believe you, but I'm okay. You're doing this for the same reason I'm doing this. We'll see who gets there first.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Here it is. Circle of Willis, the vessels are narrow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Narrow for you, normal for him. If there were problems with the vessels, he'd have had symptoms long ago.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Not if something else changed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Like?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: His heart. He could have recently gotten an intermittent arrhythmia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know "heart" and "head" start with the same three letters, but you gotta read all the way to the end.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The experimental drug is causing arrhythmia, which causes low blood pressure. Combine that with those narrow vessels, the brain doesn't get enough blood. That causes all of his symptoms. If we can trigger the arrhythmia and identify it, we might be able to stop it from killing him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Been home?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good. Do an EP study. Find the arrhythmia.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We're gonna insert three electrocatheters into your heart.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Tell Dr. Hadley I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She understands. And you should tell her yourself.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Maybe I should tell Heather about —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You're gonna be fine.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: She's just so supportive. And so great. All I do is lie to her.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What happens if you tell her?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You love her, right?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: More than anything, and she loves me.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If you open your mouth, one of two things happens. She either forgives you or she leaves you. At best, you wind up exactly where you are right now. It's noble to want to confess. Really, it is. But if the result's just damage and pain, that's not noble. That's selfish.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Stimulate right atrium.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No more conduction.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How long you plan on keeping me from going home? Until you're convinced I'm a different person, one who won't do anything stupid?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guilt fades quickly. By Wednesday, you'll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Right ventricle. And why do you want it to fade? Why do you suddenly care about my marriage?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because… if it ain't broke —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You obviously think it is broke.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You obviously think it ain't. Your marriage is like a broken toaster. Bread keeps popping out, and you keep calling it toast. Which is weird, because you've put your bread in a lot of toasters and apparently you don't see any difference. It's kind of fascinating.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He's going into V-tach.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: What's wrong?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good news. The test is working. Your heart's freaking out, but it's cool that you're still conscious.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Try to overdrive.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Didn't work.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: This might burn a little bit. Charging to 60. Clear.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Ow!

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Going again, charging to 120.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have you been dyeing your hair?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: House, clear.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Ow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The hair is growing in red.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: His heart rate is stabilized.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does your theory include any genetic mutations that could cause his hair to change color? Either he's lying about dyeing… or just dying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Red hair means it's not Kluver-Bucy. Melanin affects hair color. What affects melanin?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hormones.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Hormone panels were all normal.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Age.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's turning prematurely crimson?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A genetic disorder. Waardenburg syndrome causes arrhythmias and can change hair color.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And make you deaf. Next.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Found a long QT interval. I think it's Romano-Ward syndrome.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Explains the irregular heart rhythms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But not the ginger nut.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If he's got Romano’s, he's got at least five gene mutations. Not a big leap to think he has others that would give him the hair.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It also gives him the likelihood of sudden and unexpected death.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Beta blockers don't work. His heart can't handle an ICD.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pete Best. Good God! Has none of you ever read a history book? The original Beatles drummer. A bunch of nerves controls the tempo of the heart. They're all playing in time, except one dude can't keep the beat. Wrecks the whole thing. So we hire Ringo.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Pete Best was actually a great drummer, but I assume you mean the patient needs a cardiac sympathectomy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Probably should have just said that, huh?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Start cutting nerves, you risk his swallowing, vocal cords, sweating.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So he saves a fortune on karaoke machines and deodorant.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You think he's stable enough for surgery?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If he was, he wouldn't need it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Wow. Wow.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Yeah. Do you have any brothers and sisters?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: One sister. He told me he was on the lacrosse team.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: In high school. In college, he just cheered the lacrosse team on to victory.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Yeah. How’s your relationship with your dad?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine. You have three more questions.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: How’s your relationship with your mom?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: When did you lose your virginity?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not something I'd discuss with coworkers in an elevator.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: And… And… You know, don’t you?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A bit of a wasted third question. 'Cause the answer is "know what?"

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Okay, bear with me here. Because some people sometimes consider my thought processes complicated. I'm into you, 'cause you're hot. And smart. In that order, but both are needed. Photos can be retouched. And House is an evil genius, which makes this photo suspicious. And yet you're not suspicious. Which means either you're not smart enough to be suspicious, in which case I am less interested in you, or you're not suspicious because you know this is actually a doctored photo of House, in which case I am more interested in you. But I am wasting my time because you know this is a game we are playing on you, and I am busted and I'm screwed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I know the photo's a fake. And I know this is a game.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I'm sorry. Too bad. Good-bye. So you knew that I wasn't gonna give you anything worthwhile? An — and you were never gonna give me anything worthwhile. Then why did you bother coming out with me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I… wanted to screw with House.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: By wasting my time? That doesn't make sense. No, uh… There must be another reason. Hmmmm. Is it okay if I sit back down here?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Your heartbeat's out of control. We need to surgically sever the connection between your heart and brain.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We believe it's necessary, but you need to know the ramifications. You'll never be able to feel angina. You may not know if you have a heart attack. You may not be able to get help in time.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Where are my regular doctors?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Regular doctors?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Dr. Taub and Dr. Hadley. Why aren't they telling me this?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Brandon, I am Dr. Hadley. And this is Dr. Taub.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: What are you talking about? I've never seen you before in my life.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We can't do the surgery. We're back to where we started. Visual agnosia.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We need to reexamine neurological disorders. Something's slowly progressing.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This isn't progressing. It's there, then it's not, then it is. It's a new symptom, intermittence.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's irrelevant.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Since when is a new symptom irrelevant?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Since it points towards the same disease. Intermittence can fit with Romano-Ward. We still need to do a sympathectomy.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Maybe we missed something. Toxins.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When? When you checked every bottle, every can, every tube of paint? Or when you detoxed him twice?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Maybe there is a batch of toxic paint that he used up a few months ago.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Then he would have been sick months ago, not now.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He's lost weight since he got here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's a symptom of trying to cram hospital food down a throat he can barely get air down.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's not a symptom, but what if the toxins were stored in his fat cells a year ago, and now they're being released into his bloodstream?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So where you gonna get this old paint? City dump?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: On his old paintings. We know he hasn't sold one in ages. But there weren't many in his studio. He's hid them somewhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you're wrong, he could drop dead from Romano-Ward at any moment. You okay with that?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Just give me a few hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You got one.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I need to talk to him alone. It's about your work. Your paintings. I need to look at all the ones you've sold recently.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: Honey, can you give us a minute?

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: To talk about your paintings? Brandon, please. Tell me what's going on.

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I've only sold two paintings in the last… three years. Since we met. One was to my cousin. I've been making money enrolling in drug trials. Two, three at a time.

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: Why did you lie to me?

utterance.speaker: Brandon
utterance.content: I wanna be, uh… The way you look at me. The way it makes me feel. Uh, I wanna be… what you see… when you look at me.

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: You think I'm that shallow? When I look at you… I see you.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So… Where are the ones you didn't sell?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's not the paint, it's the drugs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's not on the drugs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I know it doesn't make sense, but I'm looking at his paintings for the last six months. They're normal April, June, and August. But they're distorted May, July, September. Every other month, he was having visual agnosia, because every other month he was on all three drugs simultaneously. The statin was one month on, one month off. I don't know why the symptoms keep coming and going, but it is the drugs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're hiding under the stairs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: In the fat? That doesn't make sense. These drugs aren't fat soluble.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said stairs, not closet. What was the last drug he was on before the drugs he was on when the symptoms started?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I'm not sure. I think —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Antacid.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How do you know?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It makes sense. Also, I'm looking at the file.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Yes? It's Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh. Wake him up. We're done.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: No, no — he says he needs surgery, but not this one.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Did he give any specifics?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Abdominal surgery to remove a… bezoar.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's like a hairball, but it's made up of undigested food. You can get it if your stomach acid's low, which Brandon’s was because of an experimental antacid. Fruit and vegetable fibers and skins get stuck together and form a ball. It gets sticky, ferments, grows. It starts sucking up some of the pills he'd taken. Some are never heard from again. But some get released. For the last week, it's basically been giving him massive doses of all three at once.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And that… is why I won't let Cameron buy a cat.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He should be fine. Are you glad he told you the truth?

utterance.speaker: Heather
utterance.content: Yes… of course.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: But… were you happier before you knew?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: About ten more feet.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I do know what it looks like, so maybe this whole blindfold thing —

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Shh. My gift, my rules. Bump. All right, if you don't like the color apparently we can exchange it, but I'm hoping. You ready? Ta-dahhhhh! Do you like it? Baby, are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: She didn't buy it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Damn. So you didn't get anything.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Nothin'. We probably overstepped. You're really not the cheerleader type.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: On the other hand, I figured she probably wouldn't figure me as the "photoshopping a photo and planting it in an obscure college paper" type either.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Heh. Yeah, about that. I took a little trip to your alma mater.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You took a little trip 150 miles.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Online, by phone. I meant I did research. That's a real photo, isn't it? Wow, that is humiliating.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There was a girl.

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: Even more so. That's too bad. You wanted her to see you in a different light, and… not only didn't she see it… She didn't even believe it was possible.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know, people hate people who have theories about people.

utterance.speaker: Lucase
utterance.content: You want me to back off?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Would you?

utterance.speaker: Lucas
utterance.content: I barely know you.
